shalimar went to Iraq with the National
Guard in 2004 her brigade surgeon took
her outside the wire several times a
week because she was the unit's only
female medic she was exposed to mortar
attacks the risk of roadside bombs and
the violence that all soldiers faced she
lost two friends when a suicide car
bomber struck their convoy but what
really sticks with her are the Iraqi
children especially those who came
begging for help after they were
accidentally burned in the chaos of
coalition raids I mean it's hard when
you have a mother
at the gate crying and her babies
screaming in pain they got third-degree
burns all over their feet you have a
fifteen-year-old come in she's quiet but
you know she's in pain she's got burns
second and third-degree burns from here
all the way down from getting boiling
hot water dumped on her and stuff like
that Shalimar went to Iraq because she
wanted to help people American soldiers
and Iraqis and she was trained to treat
these types of injuries but there
weren't enough resources to go around we
just weren't able to help everybody
unfortunately you know in 2005 shalimar
came home and struggled mostly alone
with her PTSD she says women don't
receive the recognition they deserve
because of the belief that only men see
combat the common misconception back
here is that there is a designated front
line over there and that's not the truth
the front line is everywhere it doesn't
matter whether you're on a post or not
because nothing is secure over there now
she is one of more than 8,000 female
veterans from Iraq and Afghanistan who
have been diagnosed with PTSD through
the VA system she regularly visits the
VA hospital in Tampa Florida which
boasts the nation's largest women's
health clinic we're projecting it was
projected nationally that you know the
number of women coming to the VA will
double in the next five years Peggy
Michael onus runs the Women's Center she
served as an army nurse in the Vietnam
War and acknowledges that while the VA
has come a long way in terms of caring
for women improvements can still be made
you have to understand that VA's were
typically built for your father's army
and not for to take care of women
shalimar has recently started

it's a lot more difficult because you
